Posts.Content: Yes Er & PR positive is a good thing as it means that you can have hormone therapy to stop the cancer from coming back.  If you have no lymph node involvement and you have a grade 1 or 2 cancer, then you should get away with just an operation, radiotherapy and hopefully hormone therapy. Hopefully a stage 2a

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi anonymous49  I am currently having 4 xEC, then 4xT followed by 5 weeks radiotherapy and 10 years tamoxifen. I am 44 in the Uk (NHS) and the justification were my age, that my cancer was a grade 3, the lymph node found and small cancer specs found in the clear boarder after surgery. It wasn't a 'do you fancy chemo?' discussion, it was a 'we want you to live cancer free well into your 80s and this is the best way to ensure this' conversation. They know best, I'm just a mum with 4 kids who I wanna live a long time for xxx
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: This is exactly the same as mine -grade 2 Invasive ductal Er&PR positive 2.5cm no node involvement in lymph nodes.  After lumpectomy in the pathology results 1 out of 6 nodes were found to have cancer in and cancer specs were found to be in the clear boarder. It was also found to be a grade 3 and not a grade 2. So now doing chemo before radiotherapy and hormone therapy.  Fingers crossed to you Use ER&PR positive people are very lucky to be able to have Hormone blockers to stop the cancer growing ever again

Posts.Content: Hi Titiushki,  I actually had quite an empowering experience by shaving my hair off after my first chemo to a grade 3 and donating it to The Little Princess Trust. I cannot recommend enough shaving your hair off to a grade 3 before it falls to get you and your family used to it, as after that it will go really patchy.  I sat all 4 of my children down the minute that I knew that I was having chemo and was just honest with them, telling them that Mummy is gonna get sick before to get better. That it’s just one year out of all of our life’s to enjoy a life time! They were actually fine about my grade 3 - mainly because I was so positive about it and was like ‘ look how beautiful Mummy is’

Posts.Content: Hi, I had surgery (lumpectomy) to remove a 2.5cm grade 2 tumour. Results -  Also all nodes clear apart from the first sentile node 1/6. Tumour was actually a grade 3 and the clear boarder had specs of cancer cells in. I am 44. Treatment - 4 x EC & 4 x Taxol. Then 5 weeks of radiotherapy and 5/7 years of Tamoxifen ....think this is pretty standard as buckle and braces if you a younger. The chemo acts like a broom sweeping up all the cancer cells and the radiotherapy acts like a mop to catch all the fine bits of glitter left from chemo!
